Elshaddai Muchuwa

Cognitive Science & Government · Franklin & Marshall College · elshiermuchuwa@gmail.com

I study how technical systems encode meaning, misrepresent people, and distribute harm. My work sits at the intersection of AI governance, algorithmic fairness, contextual modeling, and Afrocentric, Ubuntu-informed approaches to accountability and design.

I take a relational approach to AI and institutions:
Design from the center: foregrounding those most exposed to systemic risk rather than treating them as edge cases. Structural fixes: using context, incentives, and data practices to guide technical interventions rather than treating models in isolation. Community agency: treating affected communities as co-authors of ethical knowledge and governance, not passive stakeholders.

I am a researcher in the Computer, Affective, Robotic & Ethical Sciences (CARES) Lab, where I help build machine ethics curricula, study algorithmic fairness, and design participatory evaluations of AI systems.

Research

Current Focus

I am interested in the representational and inferential assumptions that govern how AI clusters, ranks, and assesses people, and in mitigating their impact on marginalized communities through relational and participatory design.

Much of my recent work centers on the Composite Vulnerability Persona (CVP), an Ubuntu-grounded framework for stress-testing algorithmic systems across intersecting axes of vulnerability and structural harm.

Areas of Interest

  • Algorithmic fairness and contextual modeling in high-stakes automation
  • AI governance, institutional accountability, and regulatory capacity in African contexts
  • Ubuntu and relational ethics in AI design, evaluation, and deployment
  • Decolonial AI, design justice, and participatory governance of data-driven systems
  • Voice, affect, and social perception in human–robot interaction and digital communication
  • Interdisciplinary machine ethics curricula and student–faculty co-creation of ethics knowledge

Selected Ongoing Projects

Composite Vulnerability Persona (CVP)

Honors thesis project developing a context-sensitive audit and governance framework grounded in Ubuntu ethics. CVP combines qualitative participatory risk mapping (data, decision, discourse, surveillance harms) with quantitative modeling (PCA, mixed-effects regression, counterfactual analysis) to generate relational harm scores for intersecting personas.

Teaching & Learning Machine Ethics (CARES Lab)

Co-led a student–faculty partnership designing an interdisciplinary Machine Ethics course that brings Ubuntu, Afro-feminism, and Confucian ethics into computing spaces. Applied survey design, PCA, and mixed-effects models to study how inclusive pedagogy shapes ethical reasoning across nine affective-participatory and perception-based cognitive indicators.

Human–Robot Interaction & Affect

Built interactive agents (Misty robot, VR experiences) to study how voice, embodiment, and interaction patterns influence trust, empathy, and perceived safety, linking technical design choices with ethical and cultural concerns.
